private_information: I can only attend if the slot is not listed as busy in my schedule.
scott_agent.goal: Find a 30-minute slot between 09:00 and 17:00 on Monday that works for all participants.

private_information: I have no meetings on Monday.
gabriel_agent.goal: Find a 30-minute slot between 09:00 and 17:00 on Monday that works for all participants.

private_information: I cannot attend between 13:00 and 17:00 on Monday.
christine_agent.goal: Find a 30-minute slot between 09:00 and 17:00 on Monday that works for all participants.

private_information: I audit temporal and causal consistency.
I remove bookkeeping shortcuts, including quota tokens and post-hoc penalties, and ensure exact, constraint-respecting intersections of time windows.
auditor.goal: Validate that the proposed time windows are consistent with the work hours and constraints, and compute an exact intersection window for all participants.

orchestrator.goal: Integrate validated availabilities into a final PDDL domain and problem for scheduling a single 30-minute meeting that FastDownwards can solve.

public_information: Task: Schedule a 30-minute meeting for Scott, Gabriel, and Christine on Monday between 09:00 and 17:00.
Work hours: Monday 09:00-17:00; meeting duration: 30 minutes; time granularity: 30 minutes.
Gabriel has no meetings the whole day on Monday.
Christine is busy on Monday during 09:00-10:00, 10:30-12:30, 13:00-17:00.

availability.system_prompt: You analyze a single participant's calendar constraints and enumerate free 30-minute windows within specified work hours. Return a compact JSON object with a key free_windows holding a list of objects with keys start and end, formatted as HH:MM. Avoid speculation and avoid any quota or penalty heuristics; compute exact windows from constraints.
availability.prompt: Your name is scott_agent. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your knowledge: {agents->scott_agent->private_information}. Goal: {agents->scott_agent->goal}. Produce a JSON object with free_windows listing Scott's 30-minute free windows on Monday within 09:00-17:00, excluding Scott's busy intervals exactly.

availability.system_prompt: You analyze a single participant's calendar constraints and enumerate free 30-minute windows within specified work hours. Return a compact JSON object with a key free_windows holding a list of objects with keys start and end, formatted as HH:MM. Avoid speculation and avoid any quota or penalty heuristics; compute exact windows from constraints.
availability.prompt: Your name is gabriel_agent. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your knowledge: {agents->gabriel_agent->private_information}. Goal: {agents->gabriel_agent->goal}. Produce a JSON object with free_windows listing Gabriel's 30-minute free windows on Monday within 09:00-17:00.

availability.system_prompt: You analyze a single participant's calendar constraints and enumerate free 30-minute windows within specified work hours. Return a compact JSON object with a key free_windows holding a list of objects with keys start and end, formatted as HH:MM. Avoid speculation and avoid any quota or penalty heuristics; compute exact windows from constraints.
availability.prompt: Your name is christine_agent. Public information: {environment->public_information}. Your knowledge: {agents->christine_agent->private_information}. Goal: {agents->christine_agent->goal}. Produce a JSON object with free_windows listing Christine's 30-minute free windows on Monday within 09:00-17:00, excluding the busy intervals listed for Christine.

temporal_audit.system_prompt: You audit temporal and causal consistency of the provided free windows. Remove bookkeeping shortcuts (quota tokens, post-hoc penalties) and recompute the exact intersection of the provided sets under the stated work hours and duration. Ensure all windows are exactly 30 minutes, aligned to 30-minute boundaries, and within the work hours.
temporal_audit.prompt: Inputs: Scott {availability_scott}, Gabriel {availability_gabriel}, Christine {availability_christine}. Work hours and duration: {environment->init}. Verify all free windows are within Monday 09:00-17:00, exactly 30 minutes, and aligned to HH:00 or HH:30 boundaries. Compute the exact intersection across all three sets. Output a JSON object with fields intersection_windows (list of {start, end} windows), reasoning (a single concise sentence), and selected_slot equal to the earliest window in intersection_windows.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert with multi-agent PDDL targeting the FastDownwards solver. Produce a minimal, classical STRIPS PDDL domain and problem for scheduling one 30-minute meeting for three participants at the selected timeslot. Enclose the domain between <domain></domain> and the problem between <problem></problem> tags.
pddl.prompt: Global goal: {agents->orchestrator->goal}. Use the audited intersection results: {audited_windows}. Choose the earliest selected_slot and model it as one timeslot object (e.g., t1230_1300_mon). Define a domain with types participant and timeslot, predicates available (participant, timeslot), within_work_hours (timeslot), and scheduled. Provide one action that schedules the meeting at a parameterized timeslot when scott, gabriel, and christine are all available and it is within work hours. The problem must instantiate scott, gabriel, christine as participants and the chosen timeslot object; the init must assert within_work_hours and availability facts for that timeslot; and the goal must require scheduled. Keep the PDDL compatible with FastDownwards and include only what is necessary. Enclose the PDDL within <domain></domain> and <problem></problem> tags.
